Demographic History 439
When intra-specific levels of molecular variation were assessed for L. longicaudis, we 440
observed that the ESA group presented lower nucleotide and haplotype diversity than the 441
Amazonian group, a pattern which was consistent across all data partitions (Table 2). Given the 442
larger sample size available for ESA relative to Amazonia, this observation may in fact be a 443
reflection of contrasting demographic histories between these two regions. Such pattern prompted 444
us to investigate in more detail the population history of each region, based on multiple 445
complementary approaches. 446
The network analysis placed haplotype Ll-AN04 at a central position in the ESA portion of 447
Clade 1, with its high frequency also suggesting an ancestral status within this lineage. The pattern 448
observed with the mtDNA phylogenies and haplotype networks is consistent with a recent 449
47
population expansion in ESA, with most haplotypes from this region differing from each other by 450
only one or two mutational steps, connected in a star-shaped fashion (e.g. Fig. 4). This inference is 451
also supported by the mismatch distribution analyses (Fig. 5) and the neutrality tests (Table 3) 452
performed for Clade 1 (which contains all ESA lineages). The mismatch distribution results for this 453
clade based on DS2 (less noise in terms of phylogenetic signal, with less homoplasy than inferred 454
for the control region) fit particularly well the expected pattern under a sudden demographic 455
expansion (Rogers & Harpending 1992), with a single, smooth prominent peak. Although there was 456
also some suggestion of recent demographic expansion in Clade 2 (especially when DS1 was 457
analyzed see Fig. 5), it was not as conclusive as that observed for Clade 1. The same conclusion 458
emerges from an inspection of the neutrality test results (Table 3), which showed consistent 459
support for a demographic expansion in Clade 1 (and ESA within it), and only modest support for 460
461
A congruent pattern was also observed in the Bayesian skyline plot analyses (Fig. 6), with 462
Clade 1 exhibiting a much clearer signal of recent population expansion than Clade 2. An 463
interesting inference derived from this approach was the estimation of the time frame for this 464
demographic expansion affecting Clade 1. Our results suggest that Clade 1 lineages remained 465
rather stable in effective population size until ca. 25,000 years ago, when they underwent a 466
substantial (approximately 10-fold) demographic increase. 467
468
Taxonomy 469
The taxonomy of L. longicaudis has been the target of recent discussion, since 470
morphological variation in the rhinarium (which is often argued to underlie species or subspecies 471
differentiation in otters - Larivière 1999), has been reported by researchers from different parts of 472
th International Otter Colloquium, South Korea, 2007). Although the 473
474
preventing a more complete assessment of the putative subspecies, our phylogeographic results 475
demonstrate considerable agreement with the proposed geographic range of these infra-specific 476
partitions. The ESA phylogroup largely agrees with the proposed range of L. longicaudis 477
longicaudis, presumed to occur in most of South America. The Amazonian phylogroup may 478
48
represent the subspecies L. longicaudis enudris, believed to occur in French Guiana, Suriname, 479
Trinidad and Peru. Finally, the divergent Colombian lineage could be considered to be suggestive 480
of historical differentiation of the subpecies L. longicaudis annectens, which would be restricted to 481
Central America and northwestern South America (Larivière 1999). A possible discrepancy 482
between the proposed subspecific scheme and our phylogeographic results is the indication that 483
Bolivia contains a fourth major mtDNA lineage in L. longicaudis, suggesting that further sampling 484
may reveal additional evolutionary partitions in this otter species. 485
However, any intra-specific taxonomic decision on the Neotropical otter is premature at this 486
point, given the still modest geographic sampling across th487
present data set. Although our phylogeographic results largely match the currently proposed 488
subspecies, additional analyses should be conducted employing both molecular and morphological 489
approaches, so as to further ascertain and refine the observed geographic partitions. Molecular 490
analyses should include nuclear markers, which would complement the matrilineal mtDNA 491
sequences analyzed here. Likewise, more in-depth morphological assessments should include a 492
broad suite of characters (e.g. cranial measurements), in order to complement and test the 493
perceived differentiation based on rhinarium shape. 494
495
Implications for conservation 496
The results presented here have important implications for the conservation and 497
management of this species in the wild and in captivity as well as its habitats. In spite of being 498
represented in this study by a single sample each, the divergent lineages observed in Colombia 499
and Bolivia suggest that these areas may be sufficiently differentiated to indicate their provisional 500
recognition as distinct evolutionary entities. Given the limited sampling, we do not propose that they 501
be treated as fully recognized Evolutionarily Significant Units (ESUs), but rather point out that they 502
should be a priority for further study in this regard. 503
The main phylogeographic groups identified here (ESA and Amazonia) indicate that these 504
regions have likely been historically isolated, at least with respect to female lineages. However, 505
some historical female connectivity between these areas may also be inferred from our data, as 506
illustrated by sample bLlo72, which was collected in the Brazilian Amazon but harbors an mtDNA 507
49
haplotype contained in Clade 1. Nevertheless, the genetic differentiation detected between these 508
two regions was substantial, indicating little gene flow, and consequently they may be viewed as 509
distinct ESUs or at least Management Units (MUs) (Moritz et al. 1994). Each of these groups is 510
widespread and associated with broad watersheds and diverse ecoregional units (Olson et al. 511
1998), likely justifying specific efforts in terms of conservation and management actions. In parallel, 512
to further assess the demographic distinctiveness of these units, additional analyses should be 513
performed including independently evolving markers such as nuclear loci with bi-parental 514
inheritance as well as Y-chromosome loci, so as to investigate the existence of male-based gene 515
flow in this species. Furthermore, additional demographic units may exist in the Neotropical otter, 516
and will potentially emerge as more detailed studies are performed on the basis of expanded 517
geographic sampling. Nevertheless, the results from this study are compelling in the context of 518
demonstrating that this species presents substantial phylogeographic structure, opening up new 519
research avenues targeting its demographic history and dispersal patterns at multiple spatial 520
scales. 521

76
Abstract 23
To assess levels of genetic diversity and investigate patterns of population structure of the 24
Neotropical otter, Lontra longicaudis, we analyzed 10 microsatellite loci in samples encompassing 25
a large portion of its range in South America. All populations presented moderate to high levels of 26
genetic polymorphism, and overall low but significant levels of genetic differentiation was observed 27
among the sampled areas. Although at a lower scale, the patterns of population structure observed 28
with the microsatellites were congruent with those previously reported for mitochondrial DNA 29
analyses, with the French Guiana population exhibiting the most pronounced differentiation from 30
the other analyzed areas. Data presented here will be useful for conservation and management 31
purposes, and may be used as a baseline for directing future local and regional scale population 32
genetic investigations focusing on this otter. 33
34
Introduction 35
Genetic subdivision is a very common feature of natural populations, and it is likely that 36
very few species behave as a single panmitic population, where mating and individual movements 37
are uniform throughout their range (Beebee and Rowe 2008). A wide variety of nonmutually 38
exclusive agents such as environmental barriers, historical processes and differences in life 39
histories may shape population genetic structuring, which may result in different patterns of genetic 40
structure in wild populations (Balloux and Lugon-Molin 2002). Also, it is common that individual 41
dispersal capabilities are lower than the size of the species range, so that populations may also 42
become genetically distinct by the effect isolation by distance (Balloux and Lugon-Molin 2002). 43
Understanding how the genetic diversity of a species is structured across its constituent 44
populations is important in order to reach a better understanding of historical and current patterns 45
of isolation and levels of gene flow among them (Avise 2004). Such data are useful for revealing 46
population dynamics, as well as detecting isolated and/or threatened populations. Additionally, 47
such information helps clarify if a given pattern of genetic subdivision is a natural feature of the 48
species, being a result of natural geographic barriers and/or normal behavior, or caused by 49
landscape discontinuities induced by habitat fragmentation (Mace et al. 1996, Frankham et al. 50
2002). 51
77
In this context, microsatellites have been widely used to investigate levels of population 52
subdivision and fine-scale population dynamics for a broad variety of organisms (e.g de Thoisy et 53
al. 2006, Biondo et al. 2011), as well to define target populations for conservation purposes and 54
evaluate the success of reintroduction programs (Ferrando et al. 2008, Colli et al. 2011). 55
Polymorphism analyses of these markers, in association with phylogeographic analyses based on 56
mitochondrial DNA variation, have also provided significant insights into historical and recent 57
evolutionary events (e.g. Heller et al. 2008, Urquhart et al. 2009). However, few studies have so far 58
employed such makers for studying carnivores in the Neotropics, and even fewer (e.g. Pickles et 59
al. 2012) have focused on semi-aquatic mammalian species from this region. 60
The Neotropical otter (Lontra longicaudis) is a semi-aquatic carnivore that is widely 61
distributed in Latin America (Chehébar 1990), and despite being considered to be common across 62
its range, its elusive behavior renders this species a difficult organism to study. As a consequence, 63
this otter is one of the least known otter species worldwide, which resulted in an international 64
65
studies have so far addressed the genetic diversity and patterns of population structure of this otter 66
(Trinca et al. 2007, Weber et al. 2009, Trinca et al. [in press]). Recent analyses have indicated that 67
this species harbors a high diversity of mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) sequences across its range, 68
which are geographically structured in at least four distinct evolutionary lineages (Trinca et al. 69
2007, Trinca et al. [in press]). However, no study has so far been focused on the large geographic 70
scale analysis of nuclear patterns DNA polymorphism and population subdivision of L. longicaudis, 71
which may reveal additional patterns of genetic structure, and provide valuable insights on the 72
influence of hydrographic basins on the landscape connectivity. 73
Considering the importance in addressing these issues, and the usefulness of such data 74
for the appropriated conservation of the Neotropical otter and its habitats, the present study aimed 75
to analyze a set of microsatellite markers in order to investigate the genetic diversity, population 76
structure, and effective population size of this otter across a large portion of its range. Observed 77
results are interpreted and discussed in the light of the mtDNA structure patterns previously 78
reported for this otter. 79
80
78
Materials and Methods 81
Sample collection 82
Forty-four Neotropical otter samples (blood, tissue, hair and faeces) were obtained from 83
84
captive individuals with known geographical origin, or opportunistically collected by collaborators in 85
the field. A salt-saturated solution (100mM Tris, 100mM EDTA, 2% SDS) was used to preserve 86
blood samples, while tissue, faecal and hair samples were preserved in 96% ethanol. All samples 87
were stored at -20°C for subsequent DNA extraction. In addition to newly collected samples, we 88
also analyzed DNA available from 44 individuals previously used by Trinca et al. (in press) to 89
investigate mtDNA markers, therefore making up a total set of 88 animals included in this study 90
(Fig 1, Table 1). 91
92
DNA extraction and molecular analyses 93
Total DNA from blood and tissue samples was extracted using a standard Proteinase-K 94
digestion and phenol-chloroform protocol (Sambrook et al. 1989). We used the ChargeSwitch® 95
Forensic DNA Purification Kit (Invitrogen) to extract the DNA from hair and skin samples. Finally, 96
faecal DNA was extracted using the QIAamp DNA Stool Mini Kit (Qiagen) following the 97
98
increased from one to 20 minutes. DNA extractions from faecal samples were carried out in a 99
separate laboratory area dedicated to the analysis of low-quality DNA samples to avoid 100
contamination with higher quality DNA from tissue/blood samples. Each batch of faecal DNA 101
extraction included a negative control (reagents only) to monitor for contamination during the 102
process. All procedures were performed in a UV-sterilized laminar flow hood and included the use 103
of filtered tips in every step of the DNA extraction protocol. 104
As faecal samples usually provide DNA of low quality and amount, we initially screened the 105
DNA extracted from these samples using the PCR-based mtDNA assay described by Trinca et al. 106
(2007) to assess the presence of otter DNA, as a strategy to indicate which samples presented 107
sufficient DNA amount to allow reliable amplification of the nuclear markers. Based on this first 108
79
step, only samples from which mtDNA PCR products could be confirmed on 1% agarose gels 109
(stained with GelRed [Biotium]) were used in the subsequent analyses. 110
DNA extracts were typed by PCR for 11 microsatellite loci (Lut453, Lut733, Lut782, Lut701, 111
04OT02, 04OT04, 04OT05, 04OT17, 04OT22, RIO07, RIO11), developed for two other species of 112
otters (Lutra lutra and Lontra canadensis) (Dallas et al. 1998, Beheler et al. 2004, 2005, Huang et 113
-tailed with an M13 sequence (Boutin-Ganache et al. 2001), 114
and used in combination with an M13 primer that had the same sequence but was dye-labeled 115
performed in 10ul reactions containing 116
1-3 ul of empirically diluted DNA, 1x PCR Buffer (Invitrogen), 1.5 - 4 mM MgCl2, 200 uM dNTPs, 117
0.2 uM of the reverse and M13-fluorescent primers, 0.0133 uM of the M13-tailed forward primer, 118
and 0.5 unit of Taq DNA Polymerase. In the case of faecal samples, we also added 10% Trehalose 119
as an additive to empirically improve the PCR reaction yield. PCR conditions for all loci were as 120
follows: 94oC for 3min, 40 cycles of 94oC for 45s, 58oC - 66oC (depending on the loci Table 2) for 121
45s, 72oC for 1.5min and final extension of 72oC for 20 min. PCR reactions were carried out for 122
each locus separately, and products from 1 to 3 loci were diluted and pooled together based on 123
yield, size range and fluorescent dye. PCR products were analyzed in a MegaBACE 1000 124
automated sequencer (GE Healthcare). Allele sizes were scored using Genetic Profiler 2.2. 125
Negative controls were included in each batch of PCR reactions, and were also genotyped to 126
monitor the presence of contamination. 127
Additionally, microsatellite DNA amplification from noninvasive samples (in this case, 128
faeces) is known to present higher rates of allelic dropout (ADO) and false alleles (FA) due to the 129
usually low quality of DNA recovered from this kind of material. In order to avoid such issues and to 130
increase the reliability of the multilocus microsatellite profile from faecal DNA, we employed a 131
multiple-tubes amplification approach (Taberlet et al. 1996) in which heterozygote and homozygote 132
genotypes were determined after three and five independent amplifications, respectively. 133
Additionally, heterozygote profiles were also defined when homozygote genotypes were observed 134
at least twice for each constituent allele. 135
136
80
Data analysis 137
To evaluate the discriminatory power of our microsatellite data set, we estimated the 138
probability of identity (PID) index (i.e. the probability that two individuals in a population share 139
identical genotype profiles at random) using the software CERVUS 3.0 (Marshall et al. 1998). Since 140
it has been suggested that PID (which assumes Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium) may be biased, we 141
also estimated PID (sibs), a more conservative index that accounts for individuals being siblings 142
(Waits et al. 2001). Additionally, as we obtained a few faecal samples from the same localities, 143
individual identification was performed by visually checking the final multilocus genotypes for allele 144
sharing. We also used the software MICRO-CHECKER 2.2.3 (Van Oosterhout et al. 2004) to 145
identify evidence of possible null alleles, ADO and scoring errors due to genotyping stutter peaks, 146
which might lead to erroneous estimates of population genetic parameters. 147
The total sample set was divided into four populations according to a geographic criterion 148
that took into account our previous results obtained with mtDNA data (Trinca et al. [in press]): i) 149
Southern South America (SSA, n = 55), ii) Northeastern Brazil (NB, n = 5), iii) Brazilian Amazon 150
(BA, n = 17), and iv) French Guiana (FG, n = 10) (Fig 1). Considering that we obtained a single 151
sample from Colombia (bLlo23), this individual was included only in global computations of the 152
153
the Central Andean Cordillera, which did not allow its grouping with any other sampled population. 154
Global and population-specific levels of genetic diversity, as measured by the number of 155
alleles per locus (A), allelic richness (AR) and observed (HO) and expected (HE) heterozygosity for 156
each locus, were calculated using CERVUS 3.0, ARLEQUIN v. 3.5.1.2 (Excoffier and Lischer 157
2010), and FSTAT 2.9.3.2 (Goudet 2002). Significant departures from Hardy-Weinberg and linkage 158
equilibrium were estimated using CERVUS and ARLEQUIN. To correct for multiple comparisons, 159
Bonferroni adjustments (Rice 1989) with an original of 0.05 were carried out for all tabulated 160
results. The number of private alleles was computed for each population following a rarefaction 161
method that compensates for uneven sample sizes, as implemented in the software HP-Rare 162
(Kalinowski 2004, 2005). 163
The degree of population genetic differentiation among the pre-defined populations was 164
estimated with FST indices estimated with an Analysis of Molecular Variance (AMOVA) approach, 165
81
as implemented in ARLEQUIN. For comparison, we also calculated RST, an analogous measure 166
designed for microsatellite data that incorporates a stepwise mutation model (Slatkin 1995). The 167
statistical significance of both FST and RST values was tested using 10,000 permutations. 168
Considering the current discussion over whether the traditional FST index may have 169
undesirable attributes in some situations when estimated from highly polymorphic markers such as 170
microsatellites (Jost 2008, Heller and Siegismund 2009), we also estimated a recently developed 171
alternative measure of genetic differentiation, the D index (Jost 2008), as implemented in the 172
software SMOGD 1.2.5 (Crawford 2010). The overall value of DEST for each pairwise population 173
comparison was calculated as the arithmetic mean across loci, following the recommendation 174
outlined by Heller et al. (2010). These estimates were qualitatively compared to those obtained with 175
FST, in order to evaluate the potential impact of heterogeneous levels of genetic diversity among 176
populations on estimates of differentiation. 177
As an independent measure of the partitioning of genetic variation among groups, we 178
employed the Bayesian clustering method implemented in the software STRUCTURE 2.3 179
(Pritchard et al. 2000). STRUCTURE uses a Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) approach to 180
group microsatellite genotypes into K populations regardless of the geographic location of sampled 181
individuals. The approach is based on the assumptions of Hardy-Weinberg and linkage equilibrium 182
within the resulting clusters, so that the likelihood of K is estimated from the genotype data alone. 183
We estimated the number of genetic clusters by performing five independent runs for each value of 184
K (ranging between 1 and 6) using 106 MCMC iterations after a burn-in of 105 steps, using no prior 185
population information, assuming correlated allele frequencies and allowing admixture. We 186
computed the arithmetic mean among the five runs and defined the optimal value of K as the one 187
that presented the highest mean likelihood. 188
To evaluate the presence of genetic differentiation as a result of isolation-by-distance, we 189
employed a Mantel test implemented in the program AIS 1.0 (Miller 2005) to assess the 190
significance of the association between genetic and geographic distances. Statistical significance 191
was tested u192
population size (Ne) with the program LDNE (Waples and Do 2008), which is based on the linkage 193
disequilibrium (LD) method and implements the bias correction of Waples (2006), suggested to 194
82
provide unbiased estimates under a wide range of sample sizes. We used the jackknife method, 195
assumed a random mating model, and tested the data for critical values (Pcrit) of 0.05, 0.02, and 196
0.01. Effective population size was estimated for each population separately as well as for the 197
global set of samples to obtain a general value of Ne for the species. 198
199
Results 200
PID calculations and genetic diversity 201
Calculations of the probabilities of identity indicated that the selected microsatellite panel 202
was powerful in distinguishing individuals, even in the case of siblings (PID = 2.94e -13; PID(sib) = 203
0.000032). Of all the faecal samples analyzed in this study, only two presented the same multilocus 204
genotype. Both were collected at the same locality in Rio de Janeiro state, Brazil, and were thus 205
subsequently considered to represent the same individual (bLlo137). 206
General evaluation of the microsatellite data using MICRO-CHECKER with the full sample 207
set indicated no evidence of genotyping errors due to large allelic dropout, but suggested the 208
presence of null alleles for loci Lut782, 04OT02, 04OT04, 04OT05, 04OT17, and RIO07, while 209
genotyping errors resulting from stuttering were also indicated for loci Lut782, 04OT02, 04OT04, 210
and RIO07. In contrast, no evidence of genotyping errors was observed when we analyzed each of 211
the four populations separately, except for loci 04OT02 and 04OT04, for which genotyping errors 212
due to stuttering were still indicated for one population each. However, after double-checking the 213
alleles at these loci, we did not find any evidence of such error, as all allelic peaks were clear and 214
well defined when visualized with Genetic Profiler. Different loci in distinct populations were 215
suggested to present null alleles: Lut782, 04OT02, 04OT04, 04OT05 and RIO07 in SSA, and 216
RIO07 in both FG and BA. Additionally, significant departures from HWE and/or evidence for 217
linkage disequilibrium were observed for the global data set as well as for SSA, NB, FG and BA 218
populations even after Bonferroni adjustments. It is important to highlight that these populations 219
represent large geographic areas (except for FG), so that these results may be an effect of small 220
sample size in these regions, or perhaps a consequence of finer population structure within them. 221
Nevertheless, based on the constant suggestion of the presence of null alleles and departure of 222
HWE at locus RIO07, we decided to exclude it from subsequent analyses. 223
83
Of the resulting final microsatellite panel analyzed here, all 10 loci were polymorphic for 224
global and population-specific data sets (Table 2). Moderate to high levels of genetic variability 225
were observed for the entire sample set, with loci exhibiting between 5 and 20 alleles (except for 226
locus 04OT04 that presented only three alleles) and mean expected and observed heterozygosities 227
of 0.763 and 0.593, respectively (Table 2). Individual population analysis showed the expected 228
heterozygosity ranging from 0.705 (FG) to 0.769 (BA), whereas observed heterozigosity varied 229
between 0.6 (NB) and 0.749 (BA). Average allelic richness (AR) was also highest in the BA (AR = 230
4.858) and lowest in FG (AR = 3.434). Unique alleles could be observed in all populations; the 231
largest sampled areas represented by the SSA and BA populations presenting the largest numbers 232
of exclusive alleles (21 and eight, respectively), whereas a lower number of private alleles was 233
observed in FG (5) and in NB (1). Nevertheless, when the rarefaction approach was applied, the 234
BA population presented the highest estimate of private alleles (0.95), followed by FG (0.73), SSA 235
(0.66), and NB (0.62). 236
237
Population structure 238
Global FST (0.041, p = 0.000) and RST (0.042, p =0.093) were low, whereas the overall 239
value of DEST was rather high (0.146). All pairwise FST values were significant, except the one 240
between SSA and BA (FST = 0.0049, p = 0.25). The pairwise estimates of DEST were also 241
considerably high, whereas RST values were all non-significant, except for the comparison between 242
SSA and FG (Table 3). The strongest pattern of population subdivision was observed in the 243
comparisons involving the FG against the other three populations, while lower but still significant 244
values of FST revealed the existence of genetic differentiation when NB was compared to the BA 245
and SSA populations (see Table 3). 246
In contrast to the levels of genetic subdivision observed with the fixation indices, the 247
Bayesian genetic clustering analyses performed with STRUCTURE using the 10 microsatellite loci 248
indicated that the probability of the observed data was maximum when one population was 249
assumed (K = 1; mean LnP(D) = -2786.26) indicating the absence of population subdivision. As the 250
initial analysis indicated that loci Lut782 and 04OT04 might not be in Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium in 251
the SSA population, we performed an additional STRUCTURE run excluding these loci, resulting in 252
84
a subset of eight loci and 81 individuals (we excluded those animals that presented a high 253
proportion of missing data after the exclusion of those two loci). The result of this analysis was 254
congruent with that obtained using the complete panel, also suggesting the most likely number of 255
genetic clusters as being K = 1 (mean LnP(D) = -2164.62). Finally, the Mantel test revealed no 256
evidence of correlation between genetic and geographic distances among populations (r2 = 0.09, p 257
= 0.97) (Fig 2), thus indicating that the observed pattern of genetic differentiation suggested by the 258
pairwise population comparisons was not an effect of isolation-by-distance. 259
260
Effective population size 261
Overall, estimates of Ne at the population-specific level were somewhat imprecise (Table 262
4). Point estimates of Ne resulted in negative values for two of the four populations and/or 263
presented considerably variable values across the different P(crit). Also, in most of the cases, the 264
95% confidence interval did not reach a defined upper limit, thus ranging up to infinity. Only for the 265
FG population we could obtain a consistent Ne estimate among all values of P(crit) (23.6 [95% CI = 266
11.3 147.7], sample size = 10). To verify if this issue could be an effect of sample size, we 267
grouped all samples into a single population in order to estimate a general Ne for the species. 268
Although this resulted in consistently positive values, this analysis also yielded variable estimates 269
across the P(crit) values, and the upper 95% CI continued to ranged up to infinity (see Table 4), 270
suggesting an effect of sample size on an even broader scale. 271
272
Discussion 273
Genetic diversity 274
The overall levels of genetic polymorphism observed in the Neotropical otter were 275
moderate to high (He = 0.763 and mean of 10.9 alleles per locus). Almost all markers exhibited 276
considerably larger number of alleles in this species than reported for their original target species. 277
For example, RIO11 and 04OT05, originally developed for Lontra canadensis (Beheler et al. 2004) 278
and Lutra lutra (Hung et al. 2005), respectively, were described as presenting eight and four alleles 279
each, whereas in the present study we observed 15 and 20 alleles at these loci. The only exception 280
was observed at locus 04OT04, which we found to contain only three alleles in the Neotropical 281
85
otter, resulting in a lower polymorphism than that reported originally for Lutra lutra (Huang et al. 282
2005). However, estimates of observed heterozygosity varied between the values observed in this 283
study and those reported for the original species. Additionally, a recent genetic study of the giant 284
otter (Pteronura brasiliensis) encompassing a large portion of its range (where this species and L. 285
longicaudis are largely sympatric) analyzed 13 microsatellite loci (five of which were used here as 286
well), and reported low to moderate levels of observed heterozygosity (Pickles et al. 2012). 287
Therefore, the overall variability observed here for these microsatellite markers in L. longicaudis 288
highlights the usefulness of these loci in future population genetic and molecular ecology studies 289
involving this species. Additionally, our results suggest that these markers should be tested in the 290
other species of the genus Lontra that occur in South America, the marine otter, Lontra felina, and 291
the southern river otter, Lontra provocax, since they may also be valuable for investigating 292
population genetic issues of both species, as well as provide interesting comparisons of genetic 293
variability and patterns of population structure among all South American otters. 294
Considering the population-specific level of genetic polymorphism, all populations exhibited 295
high diversity, presenting moderate to high levels of observed heterozygosity even when only a 296
small sample size was assessed (NB and FG). In spite of its smaller sample size, the NB 297
population presented an allelic richness (AR = 4.1) that was not substantially lower than those of 298
the other populations, with the largest AR being observed for the BA region (AR= 4.858). Although 299
the Neotropical otter presented high genetic diversity at both global and population levels, it is 300
301
illustrated by the evidence of most of populations presenting several private alleles, which generally 302
comprised the smallest and largest alleles in the allelic range, being usually much less frequent 303
than those of intermediate size, which were largely shared among regions. Such rare alleles may 304
be an effect of low migration rates once private alleles are inversely correlated to migration levels in 305
which the proportion of alleles that are exclusive decreases as migration rates among 306
subpopulations increases (Hartl and Clark 2007, Allendorf and Luikart 2007). Nevertheless, due to 307
the low frequencies of the observed private alleles, it is unlikely that they were included in the 308
genetic composition of the migrant individuals, so as having little effect on the genetic divergence 309
estimates such as those obtained by FST calculations (Hartl and Clark 2007) (see below). 310
86
Population structure 311
The non-spatial Bayesian genetic clustering analyses performed with STRUCTURE did not 312
suggest the presence of population subdivision among the sampled areas. Since this approach 313
searches for significant changes in allelic frequencies using simulations (Pritchard and Wen 2004), 314
it is possible that the subtle genetic differentiation observed among populations was below the level 315
detected by the program, especially if there were violations to HWE and linkage equilibrium within 316
the resulting clusters. Additional sampling at regional levels, as well as a through assessment of 317
the underlying reasons for the instances of equilibrium violations, may help clarify this result. 318
Interestingly, in contrast to the clustering analysis, allele frequency-based assessments 319
based on FST and DEST revealed substantial population structure among the analyzed areas, which 320
was not observed to the same extent with RST. Pairwise FST values were significant among all 321
populations but for SSA and BA, ranging from 0.037 to 0.132 (see Table 3). DEST tended to be 322
slightly higher than FST ranging from 0.039 to 0.22, whereas RST was lower, suggesting that genetic 323
drift may have been more significant than mutation in generating the observed differentiation 324
among populations. RST was significant only in the comparison between the SSA and FG 325
populations, which can be considered the most geographically distant areas among the sampled 326
groups. However, given the geographic distance among all four populations, the observed genetic 327
differentiation can be considered low, suggesting that some level of gene flow among the distinct 328
persal capabilities of the Neotropical 329
otter are still virtually unknown, it is possible to hypothesize that since this species is strongly 330
associated to aquatic systems, its dispersal may be facilitated by the extensive hydrographic 331
network present in South America, which would ease some level of constant genetic 332
homogenization. Nevertheless, the highest FST and DEST values were observed in the pairwise 333
comparisons involving the FG population, suggesting lower gene flow between this region and the 334
other sampled areas in South America, including the Brazilian Amazon. A somewhat similar pattern 335
of differentiation has been reported for the black caiman, Melanosuchus niger (de Thoisy et al. 336
2006) although in this study additional levels of genetic substructure were also observed within 337
French Guiana and Amazon regions, which were related to distinct habitats including the distinction 338
FST and DEST 339
87
values indicated a subtle differentiation between NB and the BA and SSA populations; however, 340
NB was represented by only five individuals, which may have caused a spurious pattern of 341
population subdivision. Additional sampling this and nearby areas may help clarify if the observed 342
differentiation is real or was an artifact of low sample size. Still, FST and RST values were not 343
significant between the SSA and BA populations, a finding which was corroborated by the 344
observation of lowest value of DEST for this pairwise comparison. This pattern suggests that 345
population structure in the Neotropical otter is not strictly influenced by the limits of major 346
hydrographic basins, as the SSA and BA regions comprise distinct ones. 347
In addition to the population structure analyses, the observed results of the Mantel test did 348
not indicate population differentiation due to isolation-by-distance. This result is not surprising, 349
since the observed pattern of genetic structure is not linear, and also because we observed low 350
genetic differences in comparisons encompassing large geographic distances (e.g. SSA vs. BA) 351
and vice-versa (e.g. FG vs. BA). 352
The observed patterns are in some ways similar to those reported in the mitochondrial 353
DNA analyses conducted by Trinca et al. (in press). A genetic partition involving the FG region was 354
also observed with the mtDNA, although in that marker most of the Brazilian Amazonian lineages 355
shared a well-supported clade with those from FG. However, even the mtDNA showed some 356
geographic swaps between clades, with one haplotype sampled in the Amazon phylogenetically 357
placed in the clade comprising all the SSA samples that were used in that study. This finding, along 358
with the observed absence of microsatellite partitioning between the BA and the SSA populations, 359
supports the hypothesis of some level of recent or ongoing gene flow between these regions. 360
Additionally, despite the low distinctiveness of the NB population observed here, the mtDNA 361
analyses have indicated some level of differentiation of this region, as the lineage from 362
northeastern Brazil (represented by only two samples in the mtDNA study) occupied a basal 363
position in the clade comprising the SSA population (Trinca et al. [in press]). 364
Finally, in spite of these instances of congruence between the previous mtDNA analyses 365
and the microsatellite results reported here, it is important to highlight that the levels of population 366
structure revealed by the microsatellites are much lower than those reported for the mtDNA 367
segments. We may hypothesize that such a difference results from contrasting male and female life 368
88
histories, in which females would present a more philopatric behavior whereas males would 369
disperse for longer distances, thus being the sex that would mostly mediate gene flow. Dispersal 370
would be facilitated by connectivity via the extensive hydrographic network of South America and 371
even by the sea. Another possibility could be related to a large effective population size of the 372
Neotropical otter, and particularly so in the nuclear genome, preventing strong effects of random 373
genetic drift. Along with the high variability, this could maintain some level of similarity among the 374
allelic frequencies in different regions, resulting in a scenario of lower nuclear genetic subdivision 375
than that observed in the mtDNA (whose effective size is four times smaller than nuclear single-376
copy loci). It is noteworthy that both explanations are not mutually exclusive, and both may be 377
playing a role in the current scenario of otter population structure. Additional sampling, resulting in 378
a more complete geographic coverage, may help obtain a more comprehensive understanding of 379
both processes and even additional patterns of genetic differentiation among Neotropical otter 380
populations. 381
382
Effective population size 383
Ne estimates from our data set were problematic. The negative and/or variable values 384
obtained from both population-specific and global analysis seemed to be directly affected by 385
sample size. Negative results are suggested to be an effect of the empirical LD being lower than 386
the expected one due to inappropriate sampling, which would also tend to be associated with a 387
95% CI reaching infinity (Waples and Do 2008), as observed for almost all of the population-level 388
estimates. Our results thus suggest that a larger sampling size will be necessary for obtaining more 389
accurate estimates of the Ne for Neotropical otter populations and also for the species as a whole. 390
The only population that yielded a consistently positive estimate and a well-delimited 95% 391
CI was that from French Guiana. It is possible that, despite the small sample size available for FG, 392
those individuals may more closely represent a real population, since they were collected from a 393
small geographic area around the Cayenne region in French Guiana. The effective population size 394
estimate based on the 10 samples from FG indicated a small Ne of 23.6 individuals (95% CI: 11.3 395
147.7), which is about half of that suggested to be needed for preventing inbreeding depression 396
in the short term (Franklin 1980). Also, the recommended effective population size of 500-7000 397
89
(Franklin 1980, Lande 1995, Reed et al. 2003) is clearly several times larger than that estimated for 398
FG population. The low effective population size, along with the considerably high level of genetic 399
differentiation of this population, suggest that this population should be the focus of more detailed 400
studies, and possibly the target of directed conservation strategies aiming to preserve its long-term 401
viability along with its particular genetic composition. 402
403
Future directions 404
The results reported here indicated that the Neotropical otter presents high nuclear genetic 405
diversity, and suggested some level of population structure that is somewhat congruent with that 406
previously reported in mtDNA analyses. The less marked genetic subdivision observed with the 407
microsatellites may be explained by male-biased gene flow, but may also be influenced by the 408
different sensitivities of the two types of markers to deeper historical events. Moreover, additional 409
genetic partitions are likely to exist among other populations of this species across its range, 410
especially considering Central America and the northwestern portion of South America, whose 411
deep differentiation was already hinted with the mtDNA (Trinca et al. [in press]). In this context, 412
additional sampling efforts at different spatial scales should be pursued in order to provide a more 413
detailed picture of the genetic diversity and population dynamics of this otter. 414
Finally, although the results presented here suggest that the Neotropical otter may be 415
considered a genetically healthy species, this organism faces several levels of threat across its 416
large geographic distribution, mainly caused by human activities such as habitat loss, water 417
pollution, hydroelectric dams, reduction of prey availability and direct persecution. In a near future, 418
all these factors may lead to increased habitat fragmentation and induce a non-natural population 419
differentiation, likely affecting the genetic diversity of this otter and how it is distributed among its 420
populations. In this context, the data set presented here can provide a baseline against which 421
threatened populations may be assessed. 422

Capítulo 5 Artigo III Molecular sexing of the Neotropical otter
(Lontra longicaudis) noninvasive samples
103
Molecular sexing of Neotropical otter
(Lontra longicaudis) noninvasive samples
Trinca CS & Eizirik E
Artigo publicado na revista Conservation Genetics Resources
TECHNICAL NOTE
Molecular sexing of Neotropical otter (Lontra longicaudis) noninvasive samples
C. S. Trinca • E. Eizirik
Received: 30 September 2011 / Accepted: 21 December 2011 ! Springer Science+Business Media B.V. 2011
Abstract Noninvasive molecular assays allow the investigation of elusive, rare and/or endangered organisms,
and are useful for estimates of population parameters. Sex
determination of noninvasive samples provides important information of sex ratio, social structure and dispersal
patterns. Still, such assays remain unavailable for most
carnivore species, precluding assessments of their popula- tion biology. Here we report a standardized protocol for
molecular sexing of Neotropical otter noninvasive samples
collected in the field. A duplex PCR assay was employed using a multiple-tube approach, resulting in reliable gender
determination for 95% of the samples and presenting a low
rate (\4%) of misassignment. This assay should foster the development of molecular ecological studies of this little-
known species, and likely also contribute to similar
endeavors on related otters.
Keywords Sex ratio ! Faeces ! Mustelidae ! SRY ! Population dynamics ! Conservation
Gender determination of wild animals is critical for understanding several aspects of population dynamics,
such as mating systems, habitat use and dispersal patterns
(Proctor et al. 2004; Randall et al. 2007). In elusive taxa lacking sexual dimorphism, DNA-based gender identifica-
tion derived from noninvasive samples is a very useful tool
for genetic, ecological and behavioral analyses (e.g. Hung et al. 2006; Zahn et al. 2007).
The Neotropical otter (Lontra longicaudis) is widely distributed throughout Latin America and is classified as Data Deficient by the IUCN (2011). Since ecological
studies and population monitoring of this species are
challenging, many aspects of its biology are still unknown. Given the difficulty in observing/capturing this species,
noninvasive approaches are critical for assessment of its
population dynamics. Here we report a reliable molecular sexing technique applicable to noninvasive samples (scat/
anal jelly) of this otter. We also report the error rates
associated with this method and suggest a multiple-tube protocol to determine gender consistently.
DNA was extracted from muscle samples from four road-killed animals (two males and two females) using a
standard phenol–chloroform protocol (Sambrook et al.
1989), and from 106 scats/anal jellies using the QIAamp DNA Stool Mini Kit (QIAGEN). All batches of scat DNA
extraction and PCR included a negative control (reagents
only) to monitor contamination. Procedures were per- formed in UV-sterilized, dedicated laboratory areas free of
good-quality DNA or PCR products.
Noninvasive samples were initially screened with an mtDNA assay (Trinca et al. 2007) to assess the presence of
otter DNA. PCR products were checked on 1% agarose
gels stained with GelRed (Biotium), and only samples that amplified for this mtDNA segment were sexed. Molecular
sexing was performed in a duplex PCR using the marker

Lut-SRY (Dallas et al. 2000) along with the microsatellite 04OT22 (Huang et al. 2005). The latter served as a positive control which amplifies a longer segment (size range:
143–227 bp) than the SRY locus (70 bp). Forward primers were 50-tailed with an M13 sequence (Boutin-Ganache et al. 2001) as described in Fontoura-Rodrigues et al. (2008).
PCRs were performed in 10 ll containing 19 Buffer, 4 mM MgCl2, 200 lM dNTPs, 0.2 lM of the reverse and M13-fluorescent primer (FAM), 0.0133 lM of M13-tailed forward primers, 0.3% Trehalose, 0.1 U of Platinum Taq DNA Polymerase (Invitrogen) and 3 ll of DNA. PCR conditions were: 94!C for 30, 40 cycles of 94!C for 4500, 62!C for 4500, 72!C for 103000 and final extension of 72!C for 200. Genotyping was performed in a MegaBACE 1000 automated sequencer with the ET-ROX 550 (GE Health-
care). Allele sizes were called using Genetic Profiler 2.2.
We employed a multiple-tube approach (Taberlet et al. 1996) with homozygote and heterozygote profiles defined
after five or three independent PCRs, respectively, to
minimize genotyping errors (allelic dropout [ADO] and false alleles [FA]). This method also controlled for possible
SRY amplification failure (false females), with a positive male identification requiring at least two independent results. In cases where three microsatellite-positive repli-
cates presented one male and two female results, additional
genotyping was performed (up to seven times), with male
identification confirmed only with C3 corroborating
genotypes. Initial tests with the known-sex samples consistently
provided the expected result regarding the amplification of
the SRY marker. All 106 faecal samples were successfully amplified for the mtDNA segment, and then subjected to
SRY/microsatellite amplification. Thirty-nine samples were identified as male and 62 as female, representing 36.8% and 58.5% of the total, respectively (Fig. 1). Sex of the five
remaining samples (4.7%) could not be determined since
amplification did not satisfy the established criterion for reliable genotyping. ADO was detected in 31.2% of the
heterozygote genotypes and FA was observed in 9.74% of
the amplifications. Failure in the Y fragment amplification in male DNAs occurred in 5.7% of the total PCRs. Spu-
rious amplification of the Y fragment in female DNAs
occurred in only 3.8% of the amplifications (female profile confirmed by at least three additional PCRs from the same
DNA).
Despite the considerably high level of ADO observed at the microsatellite locus, the level of FA was low. Thus, the
multiple-tube approach demonstrated to be critical to
reduce genotyping errors. Hence, the marker set Lut-SRY/ 04OT22 proved useful for sexing of L. longicaudis non- invasive samples, presenting a detection rate of 95% for
freshly collected samples. We suggest a minimum of three
Fig. 1 Lut-SRY/04OT22 profiles from Neotropical otters (04OT22 alleles indicated by size [bp]). The SRY marker is 87 bp long (including M13 tail)
Conservation Genet Resour
123
replicates, thus reducing the risk of misassignment to very
low levels. Overall, sexing of noninvasive samples is most useful
when connected to individual identification. The marker set
Lut-SRY/04OT22 can be employed along with other microsatellite loci to identify samples at individual level,
and to conduct population studies. Although similar
methods of sexing have already been applied for other otter species (mostly in Lutra lutra; Ha?jkova? et al. 2007; Ar- rendal et al. 2007) no previous study has focused on testing
their applicability/efficacy in Latin American otters. Thus, we suggest this marker set should also be tested on the
other related otter species in South America (L. felina and L. provocax) that present similar issues regarding long- term population monitoring.

Abstract 22
Noninvasive genetic analysis has been successfully employed to estimate ecological and 23
population parameters for many elusive and/or threatened species which may not be directly 24
addressed by traditional methods. However, none of the Neotropical carnivores has so far been 25
targeted by such studies. The Neotropical otter (Lontra longicaudis) is a poorly-known species for 26
which local levels of genetic diversity and demographic parameters are virtually absent. We 27
employed noninvasive sampling and amplification of nuclear microsatellites to characterize the 28
genetic diversity and estimate population size, spatial organization, sex ratio, and relatedness 29
among individuals of a wild otter population in an Atlantic forest area in southern Brazil. We 30
identified 28 individuals which presented high levels genetic polymorphism. By using a capture-31
recapture method we observed larger male home ranges and several instances of spatial overlap. 32
We were also able to reconstruct the genealogical relationships among several individuals, 33
allowing inferences on social structure and dispersal patterns. Female close relatives presented a 34
stronger trend for stream fidelity, suggesting a more pronounced philopatric behavior in this sex. 35
Our results reinforced the power of noninvasive genetic sampling to investigate the population 36
37
population biology, and opened up new avenues for ecological and demographic studies of 38
Neotropical carnivores. 39

Introduction 41
Obtaining reliable estimates of population size, temporal and spatial organization and 42
mating systems is an important component in determining species conservation status and 43
provides a baseline for evaluating demographic change and/or conservation success over time. 44
However, estimating such parameters may be very difficult for rare, elusive and/or threatened 45
species. For carnivores, population estimates such as census size and density are commonly 46
obtained by counting tracks, active holts, and, when possible, direct observation (Gese 2001). For 47
example, in many cases, traditional census methods using direct counting are not feasible either by 48
the secretive behavior of the target species or lack of morphological marks that allows the 49
distinction of individuals. Also, capture-mark-recapture techniques have been used (Gese 2001) 50
111
but may be inefficient due to low capture rates and the risk of injuries during handling (Mills et al. 51
52
their population biology, posing a serious obstacle to the design of adequate conservation 53
strategies on their behalf. 54
In the last decade, noninvasively collected samples such as faeces and hairs have proved 55
to be a reliable source of DNA and have become a promising alternative for conducting population 56
studies, thus providing the opportunity to work at the individual level without the need to directly 57
observe the animals (Taberlet et al. 1996, Taberlet & Luikart 1999). By intensively sampling a given 58
area, it is possible to identify distinct individuals, and thus to estimate density and minimum 59
population size (Kohn et al. 1999, Frantz et al. 2003). In addition, when associated with gender 60
determination, individual genotypes enable the assessment of sex ratio, spatial organization, 61
dispersal patterns and mating systems of a target species (Constable et al. 2001, Palomares et al. 62
2002, Dallas et al. 2003, Hung et al. 2004, Zhan et al. 2007). Finally, noninvasive genetic 63
approaches have also been employed for monitoring a variety of wild mammal populations (Eggert 64
et al. 2003, de Barba et al. 2010, Brøseth et al. 2010,) and have been reported to provide more 65
precise data on population size, kinship and individual movements than conventional ecological 66
methods (Arandjelovic et al. 2010, Arrendal et al. 2007). 67
The successful application of noninvasive molecular techniques to assess population-level 68
aspects of some carnivores (e.g. Adams & Waits 2007, Lanszki et al. 2008, Koelewijn et al. 2010) 69
suggests their potential usefulness for investigating species for which virtually no detailed 70
information is available. This is the case of most Neotropical carnivores, none of which has so far 71
been the target of such studies. The Neotropical otter (Lontra longicaudis) is a typical organism for 72
which ecological and demographic studies are difficult to conduct since it is secretive, rarely 73
observed, and very difficult to trap, mark and recapture. In addition, it is believed to occur at low 74
densities and faces several threats such as habitat fragmentation/degradation, declining prey 75
populations, human persecution and other anthropogenic impacts (Macdonald & Mason 1990) 76
leading to a perceived decline across its range (Waldemarin & Alvarez 2008). 77
Currently, most of our knowledge on its ecology derives from studies of habitat use and 78
diet, which are based on shelter and latrine monitoring and/or fecal prey content analyses that do 79
112
not need specific individual information (e.g. Chemes et al. 2010, Gallo-Reynoso et al. 2008, 80
Kasper et al. 2008). Studies on L. longicaudis involving molecular approaches are few and mainly 81
focused on the characterization of genetic diversity and analyses of population structure (Trinca et 82
al. 2007, Weber et al. 2009, Trinca et al. [in press]). Some aspects of the N83
behavior facilitate the application of noninvasive sampling, such as the usual defecation in 84
distinctive and conspicuous places. This is believed to be a consequence of the role of faecal 85
deposition in intra-specific scent communication (Kruuk 2006). Additionally, as a semi-aquatic 86
mammal, it is strongly connected to aquatic environments, which allows the sampling strategy to be 87
focused on linear surveys along watercourses. This is a methodological advantage when compared 88
to organisms that range across large, two-dimensional areas (e.g. elephants, bears, and coyotes), 89
thus requiring different strategies to allow for extensive population coverage while sampling. 90
However, despite the ease of collection of samples in the field, genetic analyses based on 91
faecal DNA can be challenging, especially when working with nuclear microsatellite markers. 92
Reported amplification success rates are highly variable and frequently low (e.g. Ernest et al. 2000, 93
Prigioni et al. 2006a). Also, genotyping errors are common mainly due to the low quality and/or 94
quantity of DNA that is recovered from noninvasively collected samples, potentially leading to 95
overestimation of the number of individuals, a bias that would affect all subsequent inferences 96
(Creel et al. 2003). There are currently several methods that aim to minimize and monitor such 97
sources of error, including optimization of sampling and laboratory procedures and the widely 98
employed multiple-tube approach (Taberlet et al. 1996). 99
In the present study, we aimed to test the applicability of noninvasive molecular techniques 100
for studying demographic and ecological aspects of Lontra longicaudis. We conducted for the first 101
time an intensive noninvasive genetic sampling of this species, which was based on the collection 102
of faeces and anal jellies in an area of the Atlantic forest in southern Brazil. Our specific goals were 103
to estimate: i) the minimum number of otters in the study site, ii) otter density, iii) the minimum 104
home range for each resident individual, iv) the spatio-temporal organization, v) sex ratio, and vi) 105
the relatedness among the identified animals. 106

Materials and Methods 108
Study area and sampling 109
The study site was located in the Maquiné valley, an Atlantic forest area in northeastern 110
Rio Grande do Sul state, southernmost Brazil (Fig. 1). The Maquiné valley comprises an area of 111
ca. 546 km2 and is located in the transition between the rugged Serra Geral and the coastal plain, 112
resulting in a landscape mosaic comprising mountains and lowlands. This area presents a rich and 113
complex hydrographic network (strongly influenced by high pluviometric levels) composed mainly 114
by narrow and shallow rivers and streams, with deep ponds occasionally distributed over the 115
watercourses. Vegetation is characterized by different stages of succession, including both 116
preserved and disturbed areas. Human influence is mainly due to agricultural use and small-scale 117
livestock activities. Some negative impacts can be observed across the area, including water 118
pollution by pesticides and domestic waste, silting of rivers, and removal of riparian vegetation, 119
especially in the lower portions of the streams. 120
Despite these impacts, the region still sustains a considerable diversity of wildlife, and the 121
presence of many carnivores is confirmed by the detection of vestiges and occasional sightings. 122
However, poaching is known to occur in the region, which brings an additional threat to the 123
persistence of these and other wildlife species in the area. Among carnivores, the Neotropical otter 124
(L. longicaudis) is commonly observed by local residents, with tracks, faeces and potential dens 125
widely distributed across the watercourses. 126
We performed an intensive sampling in three streams of the Maquiné region: i) Forqueta, ii) 127
Lajeado, and iii) Encantado (Fig. 1). We regularly surveyed approximately 10 km of each stream, 128
yielding a total linear length of ca. 30 km per sampling occasion. Field expeditions were conducted 129
approximately every two months for two years (from January 2008 to December 2009; Table 1), 130
totaling 10 sampling occasions. Each stream was divided into a set of sampling sites, with 131
standardized starting points spaced ca. 1km from each other, resulting in a total of 28 collection 132
sites (river stretches). For each site, we surveyed both banks of the stream for 30 minutes. The 133
exact length of the surveyed stretch varied among sites and among sampling occasions, due to 134
changes in water level and bank accessibility that altered the walking speed. The timer was 135
114
stopped every time an otter sign was encountered, so that the number of vestiges would not bias 136
the surveyed length traveled for a given stretch. 137
Within each sampling stretch, we collected all faeces or anal jellies that could be 138

50 ml tube containing 96% ethanol. Anal jellies were collected with a sterile scoop made from cut 142

Data quality control 205
Genotyping errors associated with noninvasive analysis can lead to under- or 206
overestimation of individuals and can result in biased population estimates. In order to minimize 207
these problems, we employed a multiple-tube approach (Taberlet et al. 1996) where homozygote 208
and heterozygote genotypes were defined after five and three independent and congruent PCR 209
results, respectively. Heterozygote profiles were also identified when each of its alleles was 210
observed at least twice. Special attention was devoted to singletons, i.e. samples with unique 211
multilocus genotypes. In such cases, their genotypes were carefully double-checked to ensure that 212
their uniqueness had not been caused by allelic scoring error. 213
The allelic dropout rate (ADO) per locus was calculated based on heterozygote genotypes. 214
It was estimated as the number of times in which homozygote profiles were obtained from 215
heterozygous samples (based on their ultimate consensus genotype), divided by the total number 216
of successful PCR reactions for a given locus. The rate of false alleles (FA) was calculated as the 217
number of times in which a spurious allele was detected in a single replicate (but could not be 218
reproduced in subsequent attempts), divided by the total number of successful PCRs for a specific 219
locus. 220
Additionally, in order to evaluate the power of the selected marker set in distinguishing 221
samples at the individual level, we used CERVUS 3.0 (Marshall et al. 1998) to estimate the 222
117
probability of identity (PID) - defined as the probability that two distinct individuals present the same 223
allelic combination at all loci by chance (Waits et al. 2001). We also calculated the more 224
conservative statistic PID(sibs), which is the probability of identity among siblings. These estimates 225
were obtained for two different geographic scales: i) a regional set of samples including the same 226
28 individuals used to standardize and characterize the microsatellite loci, as mentioned above 227
Supporting Information T1); and ii) samples from the local individuals identified in this study. As a 228
guideline, we followed the suggestion that PID estimates lower than 0.01 would be required for the 229
data to be used for population size estimation (Mills et al. 2000, Waits et al. 2001). 230

Results 300
Sample collection and amplification success 301
Over the 10 sampling occasions, each sampling spot was surveyed, on average, for 446 302
m. The linear stretch covered in each sampling site was directly influenced by water level (related 303
with season and rain intensity) and topography of each stream segment. Exceptionally, two field 304
expeditions (V and IX) could not cover all three streams due to sudden changes in water level that 305
submerged rocks and otter shelters, and also hampered walking along riverbanks. Both situations 306
occurred during the spring, resulting in a small number of samples collected in this season. On 307
sampling occasion V, only two samples were collected from the Lajeado stream, whereas on 308
sampling occasion IX only river stretches on the Encantado stream could be covered (Table 1). 309
120
During the two-year survey we collected 253 samples of faeces/anal jellies, which were all 310
successfully confirmed to be from L. longicaudis based on the PCR-based mtDNA assay. Samples 311
were collected mainly from latrines (66.8% of samples) but were also found in small shelters, 312
isolated on rocks or under tree roots (23.2%). From the total sample, 41.1% (corresponding to 104 313
samples) yielded enough quality/quantity of DNA for reliable genotyping of the selected 314
microsatellite loci. The average rate of allelic dropout was estimated to be 40% across loci, 315
whereas false alleles occurred at a notably lower frequency (8%) (Table 2). Amplification success 316
was considerably higher for anal jellies (94%, 31 out of 33 samples) than for faeces (33.2%, 73 out 317
2 = 12.962; p = 0.0003). 318

= 0.39) or genotyping success (Kruskal-Wallis [H0.05, 2] = 4.23; p = 0.12) among seasons. However, 322
we did detect a significant discrepancy in the number of collected samples between sampling sites 323
in the upstream (more preserved) and downstream (more disturbed) portions of the watercourses 324
(sampling sites 1-3 vs. 7-10) (ANOVA [F0.05, 2] = 5.26, p <0.05). Neither of these groups were 325

Individual identification and genetic variability 331
The power of the selected markers in distinguishing individuals was considerably high for 332
both blood/tissue samples from southern Brazil (PID = 7x10 -9 and PID(sibs) = 0.00078) and local 333
individuals identified in this study (PID = 1x10 -8 and PID (sibs) = 0.0009), thus revealing sufficient 334
variability to reliably differentiate individuals in the study area. Interestingly, these observed values 335
of PID were similar in both data sets, as a result of the high variability observed at the local level 336
(see below). In addition to the PID analysis, the mean inbreeding coefficient (Fis) was estimated to 337
be -0.131, indicating that mating between relatives is rare or absent in this population. 338

Of the 104 reliably genotyped samples, we identified 28 individuals, of which 13 were 339
determined to be males and 15 were identified as females. There was no case in which two 340
individuals presented the same genotype profile but were different in sex typing. Individuals were 341

detected more than once (i.e. by more than one sample in the same sampling occasion, or in 343
different occasions). There was no significant difference between the average number of multiple 344
occurrences of female (mean 4.33 ± 4.1, n = 15) and male (mean 3.0 ± 2.415, n = 13) individuals 345

defecate equally in the streams. 347

The mean relatedness (r) among otters in the total area (r = 0.1011 ± 0.009) was not 424
